reviewText:
Better than Tom Clancy's The Division on Ultra 4k, Grand Theft Auto V on Ultra 4K, Battlefield Hardline on Ultra & Just Cause 3 on Ultra 4k, Metal Gear Solid V on Ultra. combined.

Pros:
Best next gen graphics, ignore what it says up top for specs. This baby requires a Intel Xeon E5-2697 Server Processor, 3 way SLI Titan Z with 64GB of RAM. If you don't have that. You're shiit outta luck.
Sound: Some of the best premium sound quality you could ever hear.
Game play: Some of the best intense game play I have ever seen in my life. Better than CS:GO. I have no idea why Valve hasen't made this part of any big tournament. This needs to be recognize #UltimateTic-Tac-Toe4Life

Cons:
This has flat out ruined my life, I have been playing this game for a good 3 minutes.
Rekt my friendship with a good friend of mine. He beat me on a 1v1 match, he got to level one. He was so happy. Then I made a huge cuum back after an intense battle. I dropped him back to level 0 and he called me a cockk licking thunder cuunt and deleted me.

Be aware that this ruins friendships.

10/10
Would recommend this to any next gen gamer.

reviewText:
The Ultimate mode is not random. Please read the game's rules.
It's pretty nice for a free game, offering multiple modes that spice up the gameplay. Apart from classic mode, you can play a variant with disappearing symbols (so that only three last ones are visible) or try your best at ultimate mode, where nine 3x3 games are placed on a large 3x3 grid. It's really fun once you understand the rules, and you start planning five moves ahead to outsmart your opponent.

Despite multiple reviews whining about randomness, there isn't any. The active grid depends on your opponent's previous move - if they placed their symbol at the lower left corner, then your next move is restricted to the lower left grid. How difficult to understand is that?

reviewText:
This game is one of the greatest masterpieces of the 21st century.
However, let me give you some background first before I review this product:
I was born in a town of some of the most hardcore tic-tac-toe players around the globe, where we all settled our disputes with a simple 3x3 tic-tac-toe. We developed our own culture based off this game, and if you didn't have the skill, you did not belong any where in that town. I went to various tic-tac-toe tournaments across the country, winning all of them. However, the decline in interest in surrounding cities led to the popularity of my hometown to nothing, leaving it in shambles.

Untill this game showed up on Steam.

Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe completely revives the basic tic-tac-toe formula, but adds a new twist, adding layers upon layers of in-depth strats and tricks. This game includes various game modes, that are sure to pique your intrests.
Those modes include:
Classic - A classic 3x3 tic-tac-toe exprience
Classic Forget - The same 3x3 tic-tac-toe, but the oldest 4th game piece is removed, adding more strategies and cognitive thinking.
Ultimate - This is the game's selling mode, and a great reason the pick up the game. In this mode, you have 9 of your basic 3x3 tic-tac-toe boards, in a 3x3 pattern. You have to think of every move you make, and also think one step ahead of your opponent.
Ultimate Forget - This is Classic Forget and Ultimate, merged into one. The oldest 4th game piece is removed from the smaller boards.
Ultimate Forget Total - Probably the most hardcore mode of them all. This mode is like Ultimate Forget, but once you finish a bigger board, those marks can be erased as well! This mode requires lots of thinking and time to outwit your opponent.All of these modes are available against a bot, local multiplayer, multiplayer LAN, and multiplayer over Steam.

In conclusion, this game is a great masterpiece that expands upon normal tic-tac-toe, and adds a new layer of complexity. This game does not have a very steep learning curve, allowing begginers to enjoy, as well as hardcore gamers, such as myself.

Total Rating 10/10
This game has finally brought my hometown to its former glory, as the tic-tac-toe Champions of the Universe.

reviewText: Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe, what can I say about this beauty. I thought I knew Tic-Tac-Toe. Oh god, how wrong I was. When I was greeted with the main menu of this absolute masterpiece, I knew I was in for a treat. The subtle colour differences in the background are reminiscent of rural Moroccan architecture and really added the general theme of the game. I was invited to a game of Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe by my co-player, and it was there that we begin to duel, not with swords, but with our minds. Intellect and skill trumped all else, as the game arbitrarily selected squares for us to place our respective symbols in. This battle of wits was both enthralling and mentally challenging, and I was thoroughly exhausted by the whole ordeal. I would, without a doubt, recommend this blockbuster of a game to both friends and family alike.\n\nEDIT: The developer has since responded to my review, and I read the visual guide. The game makes so much more sense now, and I genuinely think this game is better than I previously thought.

reviewText:
Free, fun and simple.

It's Tic Tac Toe made more fun and complex because of the new modes.
The new modes include ultimate mode, which adds a whole new element to the game and forget mode for both classic and ultimate.
This adds more strategy to the game and extends the duration of it compared to the regular tic tac toe (which can still be played in game).
It features multiplayer that is easy to set up and play. It's fun with friends and definitely worth checking out.

In short, it's a great way to kill time and compete for a high score in a simple game made challenging.

reviewText: This will be a review of Ultimate" mode tic-tac-toe. The normal mode tic-tac-toe is as you would expect
date: and whilst the provision of full "ChalkFX" graphics and 7.1 surround sound with high quality samples of chalk on blackboard do fully immerse you in the experience
recommended:
that is not what I will be delving into in the space of this review.

No.

You see
hoursPlayed: "Ultimate" tic-tac-toe is a game within a game. It is tic-tac-toe within tic-tac-toes
voteText: and it requires you to think several moves ahead of your opponent. The rules are simple. You start with nine "Cells"
helpfulPercent: win a cell and your "X" or "O" takes over that cell
votesHelpful: construct a winning line and you win the game
votesFunny: but to do this you have to win the smaller games
commentsCount: nine smaller games of tic-tac-toe being played *at the same time* against your opponent.\n\nIt's brilliantly simple
column16: and the sting in the tail is the rule
column17: the move you make determines which "cell" the opponent must place their move
column19: their move determines which cell you must place YOUR move. Thus the game elevates from simple matters of trying to get three in a row in one given cell to attempting to maneuver your opponent into a position where they are forced to place a symbol in an empty space in such a way that gives you access to a cell that allows you a favorable position
column20: or you might play defensively and play what seems like a nonsensical move
column21: or even throw away a winning line
column22: but in doing so prevent your opponent from gaining a decisive victory.\n\nThis isn't tic-tac-toe anymore. This is chess. It's chess at breakneck speed
column23: it's a strategic knife fight that takes no prisoners
column25:
two -good- players can quickly become entangled in multiple complicated dances with several cells on the cusp of victory or defeat and then a game of hopscotch ensues as each player tries to maneuver each other into a position where the opponent is forced into giving ground.

And it's free. Emphasis - FREE

Find a friend
column27: invite them for a game of "ultimate" tic tac toe
column29:
and prepare to lose an evening as you engage in what will be the most tense evening of strategy that ranks up alongside the very best games of Chaos Reborn and X-COM.

... and it's Tic-Tac-Toe. What has this world come to.

Recommended

reviewText: Perhaps never before has a game world so perfectly balanced a feeling of a completely inviting attitude with intimidating danger. Tic-Tac-Toe could scare you with its noughts and crosses. Pfft. Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe has freaking comic sans. Every battle with a bot is epic, from the first sound of a chalk-board roar, to the glimpse of a cross through the gridline, to the fantastic swoop and crash as the monster lands and draws its cross. The art, animation and sound design for the game is stupendous across the board. At first the noughts look generic, but closer inspection reveals fantastic subtle details in their anatomy. Our favorite aspect, though, is the sound of their chalk-scraping, which also has a secondary sound like a giant flute, providing musical character and power to these mighty beasts.

reviewText:
PROS:
- Free to play.
- When I was a little kid, I played Tic-tac-toe out of sheer boredom with my classmates at school. Good ol' memories.
- Game modes called Ultimate and Forget mode bring Tic-tac-toe to a whole new level; the game can be played competitively and tying matches are highly unlikely to happen in these new game modes.

CONS:
- Despite the game being F2P, it is very hard to find human opponents online.

Final Remarks:
I never expected to play this refreshingly entertaining good old coffee break paper-and-pencil game ever on PC, and especially on Steam.

. RECOMMENDED .

Pros:

+online multiplayer

Cons:
-No tutorial

The people downvoting this game because the A.I is unstoppable are doing it wrong, this is a MULTIPLAYER game, it just has singleplayer for the sake of it, you don't play chess in singleplayer, do you!?

reviewText:
It's tic-tac-toe. Noughts and crosses for those in the UK.

This rendition is a free indie product, so at least it has that going. The base game's also free if you have pen and paper, so there really wasn't a choice regarding pricing if the developer wanted to stay competitive on the market. I genuinely dig the freeware aesthetic it has going on, sort of like something you'd find on a '100 Games!!' CD that actually cared about itself. I find those collections pretty damn sad, though, so I'm not aware of any that actually do.


As I said earlier, this is tic-tac-toe. If you actually find someone in multiplayer, or invite someone (to find you in matchmaking, of course, since there's no discrete room creation here). you essentially try to make them screw up. If you play against the computer, you set the difficulty to easy if you want any outcome that isn't a stalemate, and even then it's not guaranteed you'll not stalemate.

There's new variations of the game, which is where things get a little crazy. The titular 'ultimate' mode replaces every square in a standard tic-tac-toe board with its own little board. You try to mark the little boards and win them to make a mark on the big board. The crucial thing here is that you're not actually told that marking the top, middle or bottom of a small board dictates where the next player has to play on the big board. In this case, you actually need a tutorial to play tic-tac-toe, a tutorial that you'll only find in the community guides. It also doesn't help that the variations in small board color that let you know whether you can play there or not seem to be designed to frustrate colorblind people and those who use any sort of screen dimming whatsoever.

'Forget' mode erases the last move made that's four moves old. It's interesting until you realize that it basically means any mark that would let you win is erased so the AI can eventually win instead.


The Steam achievements - for a tic-tac-toe game, I will remind you once again - include ones for various flavors of winstreaks and for reaching 'level 50'. They also don't work in classic mode for some reason, but I digress. The worst thing about this game, really, is that according to the minimum requirements it won't run on Windows XP. That's a bit more flattering: this game is also like something you'd find on a fresh install of XP, except not quite as polished.

Despite the detached, sarcastic tone I affected throughout this review, there's genuine value to be had here. If you know someone, whether a Steam friend or an offline friend you communicate with long-distance, who you'd like to mentally wrestle while you ♥♥♥♥-talk them via Steam (because I'm not sure this game even has a chat feature), this is for you. If you're a masochist who thought chess against Deep Blue's extended family wasn't painful enough, you'll like it too.

reviewText: I do not regard this as a game but as an experience. One that, if given enough time, you will find to imprint it's core meaning and values into your personality and, by extention, your entire life. The gameplay is simple enough, but the symbolism presented by the strife between the naughts and crosses, I believe, says something about the human experience and our constant need to achieve perfection and greatness in what we do. The forget" mode in this game is clearly symbolic of the human fear of death and of being "forgotten"
date: which I think was definitely in the creators mind when they created and perfected that aspect of the game.\n\nI definitely recommend downloading this 'experience'
hoursPlayed: as it gives one a new outlook on life and presents our strongest desires and hopes in a simplified and enjoyable manner.\n\n"I r8 8/8

reviewText:
Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe is exactly what it sounds like, a tic tac toe game on steam. But will you want to play this game ?

This review will be incredibly short as there's not much to talk about here as it's just a tic tac toe game.

The game has the classic tic tac toe game and it also has a tic tac toe ultimate game mode where you have 9 boards and you try to finish three in  a row to win. There's also a game mode where some of the moves you make get erased to make  it a bit more challenging.

Overall there's really not much to talk about here as it's just a simple and fun Tic Tac Toe game.

The game is kind of glitchy. When I played it and won a match the game said I lost and erased my victory, but it only happened once.

The AI is also really smart no matter what difficulty you set it to. It will take you a while to beat the AI because more or less all your games will lead to a draw.

Overall it's a fun game and it's free so if you're bored and have nothing to do, give this game a shot. I give Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe a 7/10

For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
This new intense Free-2-Play is now available on steam stores! Made by Tigerish Games,  Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe gives you limitless hours of mind-blowing, spine-tingling gameplay! Logic-Shattering Game modes include Classic and Ultimate  Tic-Tac-Toe. Each of these game modes contain the brain-frying Forget mode. Also including Gut-Retching  Single-player, Relationship-shattering  Hot-seat (Multiplayer from the same PC), Salt-inducing Online Multiplayer, 3 levels of difficulty, Ranking System, Leaderboards, and Achievements!!!

And if you think Single-player will be a walk in a park then you are wrong! If you are having a good day and feel the need to have a dose of failure then set the A.I. to Hard mode and have endless fun losing over and over again! And if you need some salt with your fries try it's multiplayer where you'll get outsmarted countless times! And if you even think about winning well you are a cheater then!

With intense and realistic sound effects, along with it's truth-defying graphics, you'll be thrown into the unforgiving world of Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe! WARNING BEFORE DOWNLOADING: Your family will miss you and, probably, be looking for you while you are locked to your computer screen playing, you guessed it, Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe. I give this new Free-2-Play a 10/10 review for melting my brain out of excitement. Download from Steam Stores today, if you dare.

This review is also found on FanboyGaming.com

reviewText:
Ultimate Tic-Tac-Toe is literally everything you would expect from the title. If you are trying to save the environment by not wasting a perfectly good sheet of paper on a simple two-player game, then this game is perfect for you.

The game is extremely simple and to the point; everything you would expect from tic-tac-toe. There is single player as well as multiplayer options for the user to experiment with. Single player mode can be difficult at times, because the computer will beat you 9 out of 10 times. However the challenge is what keeps you coming back for more. There are also a number of opportunities for achievements. What would be nice is some sort of soundtrack going in the background while you play.

reviewText:
In the past I've downloaded a few tic-tac-toe mobile games to play while i'm in the can, and none of them have ever been as good as this. Ultimate tic-tac-toe does have a perfect no frills classic mode (i'd recommend lowering the AI if you ever want either side to win)

However, I definitely recommend Classic forget mode! This game mode gets as intense as tic-tac-toe can. just when you think you think you've mind ♥♥♥♥ed somebody your oldest move dissapears and you're suddenly the victim.

I think i'll actually keep this game installed for a long time. Would be great to play lowkey in class or at work. I think it would be rather hard to be dissapointed with this game in any way.
